item.title: [SEC-335] Add Secure/InsecureChannelProcessor supporting attribute
item.description:
Most of my URLs fall into two categories: require security (REQUIRES_SECURE_CHANNEL) or require insecure (REQUIRES_INSECURE_CHANNEL). But I have a couple links which must support both HTTP/HTTPS and there is no way for me to express this exception. I recommend two new attributes:

SUPPORTS_INSECURE_CHANNEL
SUPPORTS_SECURE_CHANNEL

Then I can write my bean as follows:

<property name="filterInvocationDefinitionSource">
<value>
CONVERT_URL_TO_LOWERCASE_BEFORE_COMPARISON
\A/secure/.*\Z=REQUIRES_SECURE_CHANNEL
\A/myspecialcase/*\Z=SUPPORTS_SECURE_CHANNEL
\A.*\Z=REQUIRES_INSECURE_CHANNEL
</value>
</property>

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: The curent implementation I am using is only for SUPPORTS_SECURE_CHANNEL. The ChannelProcessor which supports this configuration attribute throws an exception to indicate no further iteration of channels is required. While ChannelDecisionManagerImpl looks only for if the response is committed to terminate the iteration, I have a custom ChannelDecisionManager (a subclass of ChannelDecisionManagerImpl) that catches this exception and does nothing with it, as the exception terminates the loop.
Why do you need any special configuration at all for URLs which can be accessed under either HTTP or HTTPS ?

I work(ed) for a company which does not allow users to surf in HTTPS as a general rule, because it's too hard on the servers. Using SSL slows down processing about 10x compared to normal HTTP, and acceptable response times were not met when a large number of people were browsing on SSL. However, SSL was totally appropriate for a few pages in which the user really required secure browsing.

Because URI patterns are evaluated in the order given, I cannot accurately express my need using REQUIRES_xxx_CHANNEL attributes. I must satisfy this condition:

[1] These URIs requires HTTPS
[2] These URIs require HTTP or HTTPS
[3] All other URIs require HTTP

I have done this myself by writing a new config attribute, and a new ChannelProcessor which does nothing with it. I get my one or two URIs to work in either HTTP/HTTPS, while the rest require one or the other channel.
To answer directly: Without a third configuration attribute, I could not mandate HTTP for all other URIs ... because that's the default if none of the URI patterns match.

Attached is the AnyChannelProcessor class which allows me to support any kind of channel. If a URI supports this configuration attribute, the decision automatically returns; it should be first in the list of channel processors. Please see above comments for the reason this class is necessary in some situations.

Example config:

<bean id="channelProcessingFilter" class="org.acegisecurity.securechannel.ChannelProcessingFilter">
<property name="channelDecisionManager" ref="channelDecisionManager" />
<property name="filterInvocationDefinitionSource">
<value>
CONVERT_URL_TO_LOWERCASE_BEFORE_COMPARISON
\A/secure/.*\Z=REQUIRES_SECURE_CHANNEL
\A/updateLocale.*\Z=ANY_CHANNEL
\A.*\Z=REQUIRES_INSECURE_CHANNEL
</value>
</property>
</bean>

<bean id="channelDecisionManager" class="org.acegisecurity.securechannel.ChannelDecisionManagerImpl">
<property name="channelProcessors">
<list>
<ref local="anyChannelProcessor" />
<ref local="secureChannelProcessor" />
<ref local="insecureChannelProcessor" />
</list>
</property>
</bean>

<bean id="anyChannelProcessor" class="org.acegisecurity.securechannel.AnyChannelProcessor" />
<bean id="secureChannelProcessor" class="org.acegisecurity.securechannel.SecureChannelProcessor" />
<bean id="insecureChannelProcessor" class="org.acegisecurity.securechannel.InsecureChannelProcessor" />

I don't see how this works as your AnyChannelProcessor.decide() method seems to be a null operation.

I've implemented this functionality in ChannelDecisionManagerImpl, similarly to the patch from SEC-494, but without the extra channel processor. I've just added checking for the ANY_CHANNEL attribute direct to this class. If it finds it, it will return without querying the configured channel processor list, so an extra channel processor isn't needed.
This issue has been migrated to https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/596
